study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how physical activity, particularly brisk walking, can reduce the risk of diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) and how technology can promote adherence to physical activity.
results_summary: The study found that brisk walking for at least 150 minutes per week can reduce the risk of DFUs in people with diabetes, and technology can help monitor and encourage adherence to this exercise regimen.
population_specificity: People with diabetes mellitus (DM) at risk of diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).
effective_dosage: 150 minutes of brisk walking per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a 12-week Nordic walking intervention on anthropometric parameters and blood lipid profiles in overweight and obese retired miners with lipid disorders.
results_summary: The Nordic walking group showed significant improvements in body weight (5 kg reduction), BMI (6% decrease), fat percentage (19% decrease), and other anthropometric measures, though the diet group had more pronounced effects. Blood lipid profiles improved, but the diet group achieved reference-range levels for total cholesterol and triglycerides.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese retired miners (n = 30, aged 58.7 ± 4.1 years) with lipid disorders.
effective_dosage: 1 hour of Nordic walking 3 times per week at 60-70% of maximal heart rate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 12-week moderate-intensity aerobic exercise (walking/jogging) program and subsequent 5-month detraining on ECG indices and serum levels of vitamin D, PTH, and calcium in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The 12-week exercise intervention significantly increased P-R interval, PTH, and vitamin D levels, improving severe vitamin D deficiency to deficiency status. After 5-month detraining, P-R segment and S-T interval decreased, while vitamin D levels remained elevated, suggesting long-term positive adaptations to aerobic exercise.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 50-70 years.
effective_dosage: 60 minutes/day, 3 days/week at 70% of maximal heart rate reserve.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week neuromuscular exercise program combined with pain neuroscience education provides greater pain relief and physical performance improvement than pain neuroscience education alone in patients with chronic pain after total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effects of a 12-week neuromuscular exercise program (NEMEX-TJR) combined with pain neuroscience education (PNE) versus PNE alone. Results are pending as the study is ongoing, but the design suggests potential efficacy in improving pain and physical performance.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate-to-severe chronic pain after primary total knee arthroplasty.
effective_dosage: NEMEX-TJR twice weekly for 12 weeks combined with two sessions of PNE.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between light and moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (including walking) and the risk of major mobility disability in older adults.
results_summary: More light physical activity (LPA) reduced the risk of mobility disability in those with higher initial function, while more moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) lowered risk in those with lower function. Greater MVPA variability was also associated with reduced disability risk.
population_specificity: Older adults (average age 78.4 years) at risk for major mobility disability.
effective_dosage: 150 minutes of walking weekly, distributed across 2 center-based and 3-4 home-based sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fitness training, including walking, reduces death, dependence, and disability in stroke survivors, while also assessing its effects on physical fitness, mobility, and quality of life.
results_summary: Cardiorespiratory and mixed training (including walking) improved disability scores and physical fitness, with no significant influence on mortality. Few deaths occurred, suggesting exercise is safe, but insufficient data existed to confirm reductions in death or dependency.
population_specificity: Mostly ambulatory stroke survivors (3017 participants across 75 studies).

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of dance-based programs in improving motor-cognitive dual-task performance in middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: Dance-based interventions significantly improved dual-task performance, with an overall effect size of -0.48. The interventions also improved speed walking with a cognitive task, though results should be interpreted cautiously due to study heterogeneity and small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults
effective_dosage: 1-3 sessions per week, 40-90 minutes per session

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the clinical efficacy of Jiawei Shenfu decoction on inflammatory markers and cardiac function in patients with chronic heart failure and heart Yang deficiency syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that Jiawei Shenfu decoction combined with standard medications significantly reduced BNP, NF-κB, and TNF-α levels, improved cardiac function, and enhanced 6-min walking distance compared to standard medications alone.
population_specificity: 63 patients with chronic heart failure and heart Yang deficiency syndrome.
effective_dosage: One dose of Jiawei Shenfu decoction daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of financial incentives, weekly planning, and daily self-monitoring prompts on achieving personalized daily step goals using the Ally app.
results_summary: Daily cash incentives increased step-goal achievement by 8.1%, while action planning showed a 5.8% increase only in the no-incentive group. Charity incentives, self-monitoring prompts, and coping planning had no significant effect on physical activity.
population_specificity: Insurees of a health insurance company in Switzerland, who were more active and healthier than the general Swiss population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 24-week aerobic and strength training program (including walking) with varying intensity phases on physical and cognitive function in patients with dementia, and whether ApoE4 carriership moderated these effects.
results_summary: The exercise program improved gait speed during the high-intensity phase but did not protect against mobility loss after detraining. No significant effects were found on cognitive function, and ApoE4 carriership did not meaningfully moderate exercise effects.
population_specificity: Patients with all-cause dementia (mean age 82.3 years, 59 women) recruited from daycare and residential care facilities.
effective_dosage: Walking and lower limb strength training three times/week (12 weeks low-intensity, 12 weeks high-intensity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a walking intervention delivered via smartphone (SPCTL) versus a breathing meditation app (TT) on systolic blood pressure in adults with stage 1 hypertension.
results_summary: The walking group showed modest reductions in systolic blood pressure (-1.9 mmHg at month 3, -0.7 mmHg at month 6, and -0.4 mmHg at month 12), which were significantly smaller than the reductions observed in the TT group.
population_specificity: 30 adults (mean age 45.0 years; 15 males; 16 White; 14 Black) with stage 1 systolic hypertension (130-139 mmHg).
effective_dosage: Month 1: 15 min twice daily; months 2-3: 10 min twice daily; months 4-12: 5 min twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in temporal-spatial gait characteristics when transitioning from a non-microprocessor prosthetic knee (NMPK) to a microprocessor prosthetic knee (MPK) using a single-subject design.
results_summary: Most subjects showed improved gait coordination, greater reliance on the prosthetic side, and better stability with the MPK compared to the NMPK across three walking speeds; only one subject showed no improvement in any gait parameters. The BAB group exhibited shorter prosthetic weight acceptance and longer single-limb support times with prolonged MPK use.
population_specificity: Seven male NMPK users aged 50-84 years, 3-40 years post-amputation.
study_duration: 5 weeks per phase (ABA or BAB design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize the experiences of mental health practitioners and their clients regarding the use of natural outdoor spaces, including walking, for therapy to establish a framework for best practice.
results_summary: The study found that outdoor therapy, including walking, provided psychological and physiological benefits such as reduced stress, improved mood, and enhanced therapeutic outcomes through mutuality, freedom of expression, and interconnectedness with nature. Practical and therapeutic challenges were mitigated through structured approaches like assessment and informed consent.
population_specificity: 322 practitioners and 163 clients across multiple therapy professions.
effective_dosage: Not specified (ranged from sitting or walking in urban parks to wilderness expeditions).

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the effects of yoga, not walking, on exercise capacity and quality of life in patients with lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM).
results_summary: The study found that yoga improved 6-minute walking distance, anaerobic threshold, and peak work load in LAM patients compared to controls, but did not assess walking specifically.
population_specificity: Women with lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM), a rare cystic lung disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare adherence to guidelines (including walking exercise) for claudication management between vascular surgeons and non-vascular surgeons prior to lower extremity revascularization.
results_summary: Walking exercise was recommended more often by vascular surgeons (70.8%) than non-vascular surgeons (31.1%), but only a small fraction of patients (33.8% and 18.0%, respectively) were given the recommended 3-month period to benefit from it. Overall adherence to conservative therapy (including walking) was low (12.3% for vascular surgeons vs. 3.3% for non-vascular surgeons).
population_specificity: Patients with claudication undergoing lower extremity revascularization (n=187).
effective_dosage: Not specified (recommended duration: at least 3 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a pedometer-based walking intervention on body composition, specifically total-body muscle mass and fat mass, in dialysis patients.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased daily step counts but showed no immediate body composition changes at 3 months. By 6 months, the intervention group had a greater increase in muscle mass and a decrease in fat mass compared to controls, though these changes were partly due to worsening in the control group.
population_specificity: Dialysis patients (median age 57.5 years, 76% men).
effective_dosage: Weekly step count targets (specific numbers not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictive factors for gait recovery in stroke patients and evaluate the best recommendations for gait rehabilitation.
results_summary: Trunk control and lower limb motor control (e.g., hip extensor muscle force) were identified as key predictors of gait recovery, with the TWIST algorithm being a useful clinical tool. The 6-minute walking test was highlighted as the best predictor of community ambulation, and various rehabilitation techniques (e.g., treadmill training, robotic-assisted therapy) were recommended based on patient functional status.
population_specificity: Stroke patients undergoing rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if movement training during physical rehabilitation restores healthy movement patterns after TKA and reduces the risk of contralateral knee OA progression.
results_summary: The study found preliminary efficacy for movement training in remediating movement compensations and restoring knee joint loading symmetry during walking and other functional tasks after TKA.
population_specificity: 150 participants undergoing unilateral total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dose-equivalent treatment groups: standard rehabilitation ± movement training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Graded Activity (GA) alone or combined with daily-monitored walking (GAMW) was more effective in managing clinical attributes in patients with both Low-Back Pain (LBP) and Type-2 Diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: The study found that GAMW significantly improved glycaemic control (GC) and yielded better improvements in static back and abdominal endurance compared to GA alone, though no differences were observed in pain intensity between the two groups.
population_specificity: 58 patients (mean age 48.3±9.4 years, 64.7% female) with concomitant LBP and T2D.
effective_dosage: Treatment was administered twice weekly for GA, with additional daily-monitored walking for GAMW.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) versus decompressive surgery followed by fractionated radiotherapy in preserving walking ability in patients with metastatic spinal cord compression (MSCC).
results_summary: The trial was closed early due to poor accrual, with limited data showing that 3 out of 4 SBRT patients retained walking function, while 1 out of 6 surgery patients lost walking ability. The study was inconclusive due to insufficient sample size.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic spinal cord compression (MSCC).
effective_dosage: SBRT of 16 Gy in 1 fraction or decompression surgery followed by fractionated radiotherapy of 30 Gy in 10 fractions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice flavonoid oil (LFO) supplementation improves mobility functions, such as walking speed, balance, and body composition, in middle-aged and older women engaging in daily physical exercise.
results_summary: LFO supplementation did not significantly improve 10-m walking speed but significantly prolonged one-leg standing time and reduced BMI and body fat percentage. The findings suggest LFO may enhance body balance control and contribute to fall prevention.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older women (aged 59-85 years) who engaged in daily physical exercise.
effective_dosage: 300 mg of LFO daily in capsule form.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a 12-week exercise program could improve kinematic gait variables in individuals with hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in spatio-temporal gait characteristics or hip and knee joint angles between the exercise, control, or placebo groups. The results suggest that strength training alone, without specific gait-related tasks, does not improve gait in individuals with mild to moderate hip osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: 210 participants with mild to moderate hip osteoarthritis, analyzed per protocol (n = 185).
effective_dosage: Weekly group session plus home-based exercises (2/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a study protocol for a dual-task test combining the Timed Up-and-Go (TUG) walking test with a verbal task to aid early detection of dementia disorders.
results_summary: The study found that step-length and the number of named animals after the turning point in the dual-task test might be appropriate measures for examining individuals with and without dementia. The refined protocol was deemed feasible for testing in initial memory assessments and healthy controls.
population_specificity: 43 individuals with and without established dementia diagnoses attending a memory assessment clinic (sub-sample of 22 persons analyzed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine which posturographic parameters could identify fall-risk patients in frail diabetic older adults and compare them to standard gait and balance clinical tests.
results_summary: The study found that posturography had limited utility for assessing fall risk, with the most useful parameter being the area of the 90% confidence ellipse of statokinesigram (COP90area). Clinical tests like walking speed over 4m were more effective in identifying fall risk.
population_specificity: Frail or pre-frail diabetic patients aged over 70 years with diabetes mellitus for over 2 years, located in Bordeaux, France.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single fraction (10 Gy) of radiotherapy was non-inferior to five daily fractions (20 Gy) for preserving motor function in patients with MSCC not undergoing surgical decompression.
results_summary: The study found that a single 10-Gy fraction was non-inferior to 20 Gy in five fractions for mobility preservation, with fewer adverse events in the single-fraction arm. The 95% CI for the difference in mobility scores (-0.12 to 0.6) excluded the non-inferiority margin of -0.4.
population_specificity: Patients aged 30-87 with MSCC not proceeding with surgical decompression.
effective_dosage: 10 Gy in a single fraction or 20 Gy in five fractions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effects of the mHealth app FOOTFIT and FOOTFIT+ on lower extremity function, walking capacity, and physical health in minimally ambulatory individuals with venous leg ulcers.
results_summary: The study found negligible improvements in foot function, mixed results in ankle strength and range of motion, and no significant changes in walking distance or physical health for either intervention group over the 6-week period.
population_specificity: Adults 18+ with venous leg ulcers being treated in wound clinics in the Southeastern United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prognostic usefulness of the 6-minute walk distance (6MWD) test in predicting major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) after percutaneous coronary intervention.
results_summary: The study found that the 6MWD test had modest predictive power for MACE (AUC = 0.59), with shorter walk distances observed in patients who experienced MACE (290 m vs. 326 m). The incidence of MACE at one year was 22%, primarily driven by acute coronary syndrome (17%).
population_specificity: 212 patients (98% men; mean age 65 ± 9 years) with chronic heart failure who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention.
study_duration: 6MWD test performed within 2 weeks post-intervention, with one-year follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of threshold inspiratory muscle training (TIMT) on respiratory functions, functional exercise capacity, physical activity, and quality of life in patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH).
results_summary: The study found that TIMT increased maximal inspiratory pressure (MIP) but did not significantly improve other respiratory function parameters, functional exercise capacity, physical activity, or quality of life in PH patients.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH).
effective_dosage: TIMT performed at 30% of maximal inspiratory pressure (MIP) for 15 minutes, twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish normative data and assess long-term functional outcomes and health-related quality of life (HrQoL) after operative treatment of bicondylar tibial plateau fractures, as well as identify risk factors affecting these outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that patients had no difficulty walking more than a mile or climbing stairs but were limited in vigorous activities. Female gender, diabetes, and worse HrQoL were correlated with worse functional outcomes, while smoking, diabetes, and the need for total knee arthroplasty (TKA) were linked to worse HrQoL.
population_specificity: Adult patients with AO/OTA 41-C or Schatzker V/VI tibial plateau fractures treated between 2001 and 2016 at two Level I trauma centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and classify instrumented measurements for assessing motor impairments, activity limitations, and participation restrictions in children and young adults with dyskinetic cerebral palsy, including walking.
results_summary: The study found that only one of 49 articles assessed walking at the ICF-CY level of activities and participation, indicating limited focus on walking in the context of dyskinetic cerebral palsy. The majority of studies focused on upper extremity motor function rather than walking.
population_specificity: Children and young adults (ages 2-24 years) with dyskinetic cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effect of average volume-assured pressure support (AVAPS) on health-related quality of life and exercise tolerance in COPD patients with chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure.
results_summary: AVAPS significantly improved multiple domains of health-related quality of life, including general health, vitality, physical functioning, and bodily pain, as well as exercise tolerance measured by 6-minute walking distance over six months. No significant improvements were observed in emotional or social role functioning or mental health subscales.
population_specificity: 40 stable hypercapnic COPD patients with chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether eldecalcitol treatment, combined with back extensor muscle exercise, could reduce falls and improve muscle function and balance in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis.
results_summary: Eldecalcitol improved quadriceps muscle strength but did not significantly affect back muscle strength, grip power, balance, walking abilities, or the number of falls.
population_specificity: 226 Japanese postmenopausal women with osteoporosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the segmental motion and radiological severity of overcorrected clubfeet (OCCF) caused by surgery versus Ponseti treatment during walking.
results_summary: The study found no significant radiological differences between OCCF groups except in the calcaneal inclination angle, which was more pathological in the Ponseti group. Surgically treated feet showed reduced ankle plantar flexion and hindfoot motion in the frontal plane during walking compared to the Ponseti group.
population_specificity: Children aged 7-12 years with overcorrected clubfeet (OCCF), divided into surgical (18 feet) and Ponseti (14 feet) groups, with 25 typically developing children as controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate adherence to clinical guidance on walking frame use, quantify user stability, and explore user and healthcare professional perspectives on walking aids and Smart Walkers.
results_summary: Incorrect use of walking frames was observed in 16% of single support and 29% of dual support periods, linked to environmental constraints and frame design, and associated with reduced stability. Participants and healthcare professionals viewed Smart Walker technology positively, but current guidance needs improvement to enhance stability and safety.
population_specificity: Older adults using walking frames in their home environment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate assessments of gait and functional ambulation in children with neuromuscular diseases to document disease progression and treatment efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that gait speed is an indicator of disability, with children affected by neuromuscular diseases walking slower than typically developing peers. The six-minute walk test showed reduced endurance and ambulatory capacity across all pediatric neuromuscular diseases, particularly in conditions like spinal muscular atrophy type 3 and Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
population_specificity: Children aged 0-18 years with pediatric neuromuscular diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the 2-year efficacy and safety of paclitaxel drug-coated balloon (DCB) angioplasty versus conventional balloon angioplasty for treating femoropopliteal lesions in peripheral artery disease.
results_summary: At 2 years, DCB angioplasty showed superior primary patency (90.2%) compared to conventional balloon angioplasty (62.7%). Secondary outcomes, including target lesion revascularization and clinical improvement, were also evaluated.
population_specificity: Symptomatic patients with superficial femoral and/or popliteal artery disease (mean age 69 years, predominantly male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a combined aerobic exercise and cognitive training intervention on dual-task walking performance in healthy older adults.
results_summary: The study found that participants in the combined aerobic exercise and cognitive training group (EXCOG) showed significant improvements in cognitive performance during dual-task walking, with effects twice as large as other groups. No significant changes were observed in dual-task gait measures across any group.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling, healthy older adults (n=74).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved 12 weeks of cognitive training and aerobic exercise, but exact dosage/frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a peer-led workplace walking intervention for physically inactive employees.
results_summary: The intervention was feasible, with mixed efficacy results: cardio-metabolic risk markers improved in the enhanced treatment group, autonomous motivation increased in both groups, but no changes were observed in step counts, standing, sitting time, or well-being.
population_specificity: Physically inactive employees

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early and intense lower extremity training using a recumbent cycle ergometer system improves motor control and walking recovery in patients with acute ischemic stroke.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in Fugl-Meyer Assessment scores, Berg Balance Scale scores, and Barthel index compared to the control group, particularly at 2 and 4 weeks. However, no significant differences were observed in unassisted walking or modified Rankin Score between groups at 3 months.
population_specificity: Patients with acute ischemic stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an evidence-based discharge planning intervention (HOME) improved outcomes like independence in ADL, participation in life roles, and reduced unplanned re-hospitalizations and ED presentations, particularly in at-risk subgroups including those with walking difficulty.
results_summary: The study found that the HOME intervention significantly reduced unplanned hospitalizations in older adults with mild cognitive impairment, but walking difficulty was not specifically highlighted in the significant results.
population_specificity: Hospitalized older adults (n=400) with acute and medical conditions, including subgroups with mild cognitive impairment, walking difficulty, comorbidity, living alone, and no family support.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating gait training with the Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL) improved walking outcomes in subacute stroke patients with severe walking limitations compared to conventional gait training.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in walking independence or secondary outcomes between HAL training and conventional gait training groups. However, two-thirds of all patients achieved walking independence by 6 months, with age being a predictor of outcome.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients with severe limitations in walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of FES-cycling training on motor recovery and walking ability in subacute stroke survivors using neuro-mechanical analysis.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in clinical scales, gait parameters, and work produced by the affected leg after training. Synergy analysis indicated re-learning of a more physiological motor strategy, particularly in knee flexion during pedaling.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke survivors (median age 75 years, median time post-stroke 2 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether initiating physical activity (walking) could prevent major mobility disability in sedentary older adults.
results_summary: The physical activity program reduced the risk of major mobility disability (inability to walk 400 m) compared to health education, with no significant effects on cognitive outcomes, cardiovascular events, or serious fall injuries. The intervention was also found to be cost-effective.
population_specificity: Sedentary older adults (1,635 participants randomized at eight U.S. sites).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preconditioning local vibrations reduce reactive hyperemia after walking in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found that peak skin blood flow (SBF) was significantly lower in the vibration protocol compared to the sham control, suggesting that local vibrations may reduce reactive hyperemia after walking.
population_specificity: 10 healthy participants without diabetes mellitus (DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of progressive dual-task training (variable- to fixed-priority instructions) versus variable-priority dual-task training on gait speed and other functional outcomes in older adults.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a rigorous randomized controlled trial design but does not report specific results, as it appears to be a study protocol rather than a completed study. The intended outcomes include gait speed, postural balance, executive function, falls, and quality of life.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged 60-80 years.
effective_dosage: 48 sessions of 60 minutes each over 24 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify and compare joint and leg stiffness, skeletal and muscular contributions, and associated joint angles and moments in the affected and nonaffected limbs during walking in children with spastic hemiplegic cerebral palsy (HCP).
results_summary: The study found altered joint kinematics and kinetics in the nonaffected limb of HCP children, likely as a compensatory strategy to minimize bilateral asymmetry in leg and joint stiffness during walking phases. The results suggest therapeutic planning should consider mechanics of both the affected and nonaffected sides.
population_specificity: 12 children with spastic hemiplegic cerebral palsy (HCP) and 12 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the consistency of preference reporting in nursing home residents, comparing VA and non-VA groups, and identify factors influencing reliability, including walking independence.
results_summary: The study found that non-VA nursing home residents had higher agreement in preference reporting, with walking independence being a predictor of reliability in this group. Overall, better agreement was associated with being female, non-VA, and having better cognition.
population_specificity: Veteran (VA) and non-VA nursing home residents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the functional outcomes of different non-operative treatments (rigid sole shoe vs. boot) for spiral diaphyseal fractures of the fifth metatarsal.
results_summary: Patients treated with a rigid sole shoe had significantly shorter recovery times (pain-free walking and return to normal footwear) and reported less restriction compared to those treated with a boot. All fractures healed with conservative management, though three cases showed delayed union.
population_specificity: 33 consecutive patients with spiral diaphyseal fractures of the fifth metatarsal treated at a central London teaching hospital.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (non-operative treatment modalities: rigid sole shoe or boot).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 6 months of cocoa consumption improved walking performance in people with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found preliminary evidence suggesting a therapeutic effect of cocoa on walking performance in PAD patients, though further research is needed for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: People with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: 15 g of cocoa and 75 mg of epicatechin daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association of peripheral artery disease (PAD) with longitudinal life-space mobility trajectory in older adults.
results_summary: Participants with PAD experienced a more rapid decline in life-space mobility (-1.1 points per year) compared to those without PAD, with adjusted mean scores at 5-year follow-up indicating restricted mobility at the neighborhood level. PAD was also associated with higher mortality, particularly in those with life-space restriction.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (mean age 75.7 years, 50.5% female, 50.4% African American).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the Mobile Device Outcomes-based Rehabilitation Program (MDORP) improved strength, mobility, and gait quality in service members and Veterans with lower limb amputation.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in hip extensor strength, basic and high-level mobility, musculoskeletal endurance, and gait quality after an 8-week intervention using the ReLOAD mobile sensor system.
population_specificity: Service members (7) and Veterans (10) with lower limb amputation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether combining multicomponent training with active or sham tDCS could enhance and prolong functional capacity improvements in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that tDCS could potentiate and extend the benefits of multicomponent training on functional capacity, but results were not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals from the community.
effective_dosage: tDCS administered at 2 mA for 20 minutes during training sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of total ankle replacement versus ankle arthrodesis in improving pain-free function for patients with end-stage ankle osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The abstract describes the statistical analysis plan for the trial but does not report results, as the study was still ongoing at the time of writing.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage ankle osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foot orthoses could improve gait distance and reduce postural sway after walking, as measured by the Six-Minute Walk Test (6MWT), in normal-weight and obese individuals with foot malalignment.
results_summary: The study found that four weeks of foot orthosis intervention significantly improved ambulatory performance during the 6MWT, reduced fatigue sensation, and decreased post-walking postural sway, with greater benefits observed in obese participants.
population_specificity: Ten normal-weight and ten obese individuals with foot malalignment and/or abnormal foot arch.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effectiveness of physical activity interventions, including walking, for improving outcomes like balance, mobility, and well-being in visually impaired adults.
results_summary: Walking was one of several physical activity interventions studied, with significant improvements noted in functional capacity and falls/balance-related outcomes in some studies, though meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials showed non-significant effects on specific balance measures.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 years and older with visual impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if fampridine-MR improves upper limb function in MS patients and if it alters electrophysiological parameters predictive of treatment response.
results_summary: Fampridine-MR showed no clinical benefit for upper limb function, vision, or fatigue, nor any measurable effect on electrophysiological parameters. It was well-tolerated with few serious adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with MS of any subtype, duration, and severity who had symptomatic upper limb impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure the prevalence of and risk factors for chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) and deep venous thrombosis (DVT) among health care workers due to prolonged standing and walking.
results_summary: The study found a high prevalence of clinical CVI and venous reflux among health care workers, despite low cardiovascular comorbidities, highlighting the need for increased awareness and preventive strategies.
population_specificity: Hospital employees (93.0% women, median age 42 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety, efficacy, and recovery outcomes of functional bracing (allowing early walking) versus traditional plaster casting for non-operative treatment of Achilles tendon rupture.
results_summary: Functional bracing showed a statistically significant improvement in recovery at 8 weeks compared to plaster casting, but no significant differences were observed at 3, 6, or 9 months. Both treatments had similar complication rates, including re-rupture, and no difference in resource use.
population_specificity: 540 adult patients (79% male, mean age 48.7 years) with Achilles tendon rupture treated non-operatively at 39 NHS hospitals in the UK.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (interventions were plaster cast or functional brace, not a walking dosage).
study_duration: 8 weeks of intervention, with follow-up assessments at 3, 6, and 9 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish cutoff values for sections of the BESTest to differentiate between fast and slow walkers among older women with hip fracture.
results_summary: The study found that five sections of the BESTest could differentiate between fast and slow walkers, with Section IV-Stability in Gait showing the highest predictive accuracy (AUC = 0.92). Balance during gait and anticipatory postural adjustments were identified as key components for achieving faster walking speeds.
population_specificity: Older women (65 years or older) with hip fracture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined transepicardial and transseptal implantation of CD133+ stem cells during CABG improves cardiac function and quality of life, assessed via a 6-minute walking test, in patients with low ejection fraction.
results_summary: The CD133+ group showed significant improvements in ejection fraction, wall motion score index, scar size proportion, and quality of life (measured by a 6-minute walking test) compared to the control group, though no improvement was seen in the MLHFQ scale.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with coronary heart disease and ejection fraction <35%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of video-based exergaming training on walking, among other functions, in persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking and lower extremity functions in both the video-based exergaming and conventional rehabilitation groups, with video-based exergaming being almost as effective as conventional rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if conventional physiotherapy, including walking, could improve balance in chronic stroke patients (ICHS or IS) after later intervention.
results_summary: The study found that ischemic stroke (IS) patients showed significant balance improvements in posturographic assessments after physiotherapy, while no such improvements were observed in intracerebral hemorrhagic stroke (ICHS) patients. No differences were noted in clinical balance scales for either group.
population_specificity: 34 chronic stroke patients with unilateral ICHS or IS involving motor cortex or sub-cortical areas.
effective_dosage: 20 sessions of 60 minutes, 3 times per week (including walking and other large-muscle activities).
study_duration: Approximately 7 weeks (20 sessions over 3 sessions per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors for nonunion in patients with acute osteoporotic vertebral fractures (OVFs) and compare outcomes between union and nonunion groups, including walking ability.
results_summary: Patients with nonunion at 48 weeks had lower walking ability scores (JOABPEQ) compared to those with union. MRI patterns and vertebral compression percentage were identified as independent risk factors for nonunion.
population_specificity: Female patients aged 65 to 85 years with acute one-level osteoporotic compression fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how different foot orthosis (FO) designs (medial posting, lateral posting, arch support, or arch & heel support) alter lower limb kinematics and kinetics during walking.
results_summary: Medial posting reduced peak ankle eversion moment, while lateral posting increased peak ankle dorsiflexion, eversion, and abduction moment while decreasing knee adduction moment. Arch-supported and heel-supported FOs slightly decreased vertical ground reaction force but not significantly.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with lower extremity abnormalities implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop new prediction equations for maximal oxygen consumption (V̇O₂) using the 6-Minute Walking Test (6MWT) in childhood ALL survivors.
results_summary: The study established new clinical V̇O₂ prediction equations based on the 6MWT, suggesting its utility in assessing cardiorespiratory fitness in this population. The abstract implies the 6MWT is a viable method for functional capacity evaluation, though full results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) survivors (n=200, with 168 undergoing tests).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether flywheel resistance exercise training improved muscle strength, muscle power, and physical function (including walking speed) in older adults.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in knee flexion torque, mean power, and performance in the 30-second Chair Sit-Stand Test (CST) in the exercise group, with no substantial differences in the control group. Walking speed was assessed but specific results were not highlighted in the abstract.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (64 ± 5 years)
effective_dosage: 4 sets of 9 maximal repetitions on a flywheel squat device

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness, safety, and compliance of Zheng's Supine Rehabilitation Exercise (ZSRE) in elderly patients with acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (AECOPD).
results_summary: The study found that ZSRE significantly improved COPD Assessment Test (CAT) scores, 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), and Modified Medical Research Council Dyspnea Scale (mMRC) scores in the rehabilitation group compared to the control group. Improvements were noted at the 9th week post-discharge compared to admission or discharge.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with acute exacerbation of severe or extremely severe COPD.
effective_dosage: Not specified (ZSRE started on the second day of admission and continued until 8 weeks after discharge).
study_duration: From the second day of admission until 8 weeks after discharge.

study_goal: To investigate whether rigorous aerobic exercise (stationary bicycle training) is feasible for people with cerebellar degeneration and to assess its clinical impact on ataxia severity, balance, and gait.
results_summary: Aerobic training was feasible for most participants, with improvements in ataxia severity (mean reduction of 2.1 points), walking speed, balance, and fitness. The control group showed a slight worsening of ataxia severity (increase of 0.3 points).
population_specificity: Twenty individuals with cerebellar degeneration caused by genetic disorders (mean age 50 years).
effective_dosage: Five 30-minute sessions per week at 65%-80% of maximal heart rate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and feasibility of a new robotic exoskeleton for assisting walking in individuals with motor-complete spinal cord injuries.
results_summary: The study found improvements in walking distance (6MWT) and speed (10MWT), as well as enhanced Hoffer walking ability grade, SCIM, and WISCI II scores after 2 weeks of exoskeletal-assisted walking. No improvement in lower extremity motor score was observed, and adverse event rates were 21% (non-serious) and 4% (serious).
population_specificity: Individuals aged 15-75 with motor-complete spinal cord injuries (T6-L1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait characteristics in laboratory and real-life settings in children with cerebral palsy (CP) and typical development (TD).
results_summary: Most gait characteristics differed between laboratory and daily life settings in both groups. Children with CP showed numerous high correlations between laboratory and daily life gait parameters, while fewer correlations were found in the TD group, indicating better performance in clinical settings for CP children.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (CP) and children with typical development (TD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the predictive capabilities of preoperative usual and maximal gait speeds for functional recovery in patients after total hip arthroplasty (THA).
results_summary: The study found that maximal gait speed was a better predictor of functional recovery (unassisted walking 5 days postoperatively) than usual gait speed, with an AUC of 0.70, matching the predictive ability of a clinical model including age, sex, leg muscle strength, and ROM.
population_specificity: 317 patients who underwent primary and unilateral THA.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (gait speed was measured, not administered).
study_duration: Functional recovery was assessed 5 days postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of land-based exercise therapy (LBET) and heated-water exercise therapy (HWET) on cardiovascular function, exercise tolerance, physical function, and body composition in PAD patients.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that both LBET and HWET are effective interventions for PAD, but the comparative efficacy between the two was not previously clear. The study sought to elucidate these differences.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two frailty indices (modified-Krishnan's FI and CSHA-FI) in predicting postoperative outcomes, including mortality, hip function, and recovery of daily activities, in elderly hip fracture patients.
results_summary: The modified-Krishnan's FI showed higher predictive validity for 3-month mortality (AUC = 0.856) compared to CSHA-FI (AUC = 0.793) and was more consistently associated with recovery of hip function and daily activities.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mean age 77.5 ± 8.5 years, 67% female) with hip fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a 6-week virtual reality (VR) rehabilitation program versus a conventional rehabilitation program in improving balance, gait, upper limb performance, and quality of life in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The VR rehabilitation program significantly improved balance (BBS), gait adaptability (DGI), and mental quality of life (SF-36), while reducing upper limb disability (DASH). The conventional program only showed improvement in upper limb disability (DASH).
population_specificity: Fifty-one outpatients with Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: To explore the feasibility and acceptability of a web-based walking intervention for people with long-term musculoskeletal conditions (LTMCs) and determine the feasibility of a definitive trial.
results_summary: The intervention was feasible, acceptable, and had high adherence with no adverse events. The six-minute walk test and step count were suitable outcomes, but accelerometry was not. A future phase III trial with 216 participants is recommended.
population_specificity: Adults with mild/moderate long-term musculoskeletal conditions doing less than 120 minutes of moderate-intensity activity per week.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking program details not quantified).
study_duration: 6 months (with assessments at baseline, 3, and 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of water-based exercises on walking speed, balance, and strength in adults who have had a stroke.
results_summary: The study found moderate-quality evidence that water-based exercises significantly improved walking speed and balance compared to land-based exercises, but no significant change in strength. The benefits, though statistically significant, were small and may not be clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults who have had a stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how modifiable and non-modifiable factors influence prosthetic functional mobility, using both patient-reported and performance-based measures.
results_summary: The study found that both modifiable (balance ability, confidence, prosthesis use) and non-modifiable factors (sex, amputation cause, surgical level) explained variance in functional mobility. Performance-based walking was linked to balance and confidence, while patient-reported function was influenced by prosthesis use, walking speed, and comorbidities.
population_specificity: 305 volunteers with lower limb loss (69% men, mean age 56 years; 52% vascular amputation causes, 42% above-knee surgical levels, 82% with comorbidities).

study_goal: To determine the effects of a 10-week exercise intervention (emphasizing brisk walking) compared with health education on fatigue, quality of life, and functional fitness in fatigued cancer survivors.
results_summary: The exercise intervention significantly reduced fatigue, improved cognitive function, global quality of life, and functional fitness, while also reducing insomnia and fear of physical activity. These effects were maintained at 26 weeks, with no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Post-treatment fatigued cancer survivors (33 female, 30 breast cancer, aged 55 ± 2 years, time since treatment 2.3 ± 0.3 years).
effective_dosage: Progressive increments of brisk walking (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether using an abdominal binder after gynecologic laparoscopy improved recovery, including postoperative walking ability.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in postoperative walking ability, pain, or respiratory function between patients using an abdominal binder and the control group. The abdominal binder did not enhance recovery in terms of physical activity.
population_specificity: Patients scheduled for gynecologic laparoscopy (n=66).
study_duration: Assessed at 12, 24, and 48 hours after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of an app-based intervention versus supervised exercise and health coaching in increasing physical activity, cardiorespiratory fitness, and improving body composition in adults with mobility disability.
results_summary: Both app-based and supervised interventions moderately improved cardiorespiratory fitness and body composition over 12 weeks, with no significant differences between groups. Neither intervention increased moderate-to-vigorous physical activity levels.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-45 with self-perceived mobility disability (81.8% women).
effective_dosage: Not specified (commercially available apps or 1 weekly supervised session + coaching).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a test (Time to be Ready to Void, TRV) to assess the total time required for individuals with multiple sclerosis to prepare for micturition, considering mobility and other factors.
results_summary: The TRV demonstrated excellent inter-rater reliability and good to moderate test-retest reliability, with strong correlations between the mobility stage and established mobility tests. Most participants rated the test's comprehension, acceptance, and relevance as good.
population_specificity: 71 individuals with multiple sclerosis (mean age 54.4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the IPACK block provides additional pain relief benefits compared to a sham injection in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The IPACK group showed lower pain scores at rest in the PACU, but no significant differences were found in pain during physical therapy, opioid consumption, walking distance, or length of stay. The clinical significance of the pain reduction was deemed minimal.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (35 in the IPACK group, 34 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the neuroanatomical and physiological underpinnings of sadness, including its effects on walking speed and posture.
results_summary: The study found that sadness is associated with reduced walking speed and slumped posture, linked to specific neuroanatomical and electrophysiological changes, including reduced left frontal asymmetry and cortical activation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of sadness mechanisms)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop meaningful cut-points for the Figure-of-8-Walk test (F8WT) to assess mobility and balance in older adults and evaluate its association with negative outcomes like falls and hospitalizations.
results_summary: The study identified specific F8WT performance times (≤9.09 and ≤9.27 seconds) and step counts (≤17) that effectively discriminate mobility and balance levels. Those who performed well on the F8WT had significantly lower incidences of falls, emergency visits, and hospitalizations (44%-59% lower risk).
population_specificity: 421 community-dwelling older adults (mean age 80.7 ± 7.8 years).
study_duration: Intervention duration not specified; follow-up lasted 12 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to compare the effects of different bronchoscopic lung volume reduction (BLVR) treatments on patients with emphysema, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that BLVR treatments, such as EBV and BTVA, showed significant improvements in FEV1, 6MWD, and SGRQ compared to medical care, but the abstract does not mention Walking.
population_specificity: Patients with emphysema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the evidence for physical interventions, including walking-related therapies, for freezing of gait (FOG) and gait impairments in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients and establish clinical recommendations.
results_summary: The study found that visual and auditory cueing, treadmill walking, aquatic obstacle training, and supervised slackline training significantly reduced FOG in PD patients. Treadmill training and auditory/visual cues also improved gait kinematics, while other interventions like balance training and tactile cues showed potential but require further investigation.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients experiencing freezing of gait or gait impairments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of early cycle ergometer use versus standard physiotherapy for improving post-cardiac surgery mobility.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the total number of steps between the cycle ergometer group and the standard care group, indicating that the ergometer did not enhance mobility more than standard physiotherapy. However, the intervention was deemed safe and potentially motivational for patients.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent elective cardiac surgery (valvular or coronary bypass surgery via sternotomy).
study_duration: From immediately post-extubation until discharge from the intensive care unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a self-monitoring comprehensive geriatric intervention programme (CGIP) delivered via weekly class-styled sessions versus a home-based programme on physical function and muscle size in older adults to prevent sarcopenia and/or frailty.
results_summary: Both interventions significantly improved knee extension strength, normal walking speed, and muscle thickness, with greater improvements in knee extension strength and additional benefits in maximum walking speed and timed up-and-go observed in the class-styled group. The home-based intervention was deemed cost-effective and beneficial for preventing sarcopenia and/or frailty in older adults.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (average age 74, ~58% women).
effective_dosage: 90-minute weekly sessions for the class-styled group; home-based group received instructions for independent execution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and acceptability of an exoskeleton-based gait rehabilitation program for individuals with stroke compared to usual physical therapy care.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a mixed-methods approach to assess walking recovery, motor function, and quality of life, but specific results are not yet available as it describes a planned trial.
population_specificity: Adults with subacute stroke from three inpatient rehabilitation hospitals.
study_duration: Outcome data will be collected at baseline, post-intervention, and at 6 months (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a strong desire to void on walking speed in individuals with multiple sclerosis (IwMS) and lower urinary tract symptoms, and to identify clinical or urodynamic factors associated with walking speed impairment.
results_summary: The study found that a strong desire to void (SDV) was associated with reduced walking speed in IwMS, suggesting a clinical impact of bladder sensation on gait. No individual characteristics predicted a greater decrease in gait velocity at SDV.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (IwMS) and urinary disorders, with an Expanded Disability Status Scale score <7.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical and cost-effectiveness of The Daily Mile, a 15-minute daily walking or running intervention, in reducing BMI z-scores in children.
results_summary: The Daily Mile had a small but non-significant overall effect on BMI z-scores, but showed a moderate benefit in girls, making it cost-effective for them. The intervention was not cost-effective for boys.
population_specificity: School children (1,153 intervention, 1,127 control participants).
effective_dosage: 15 minutes daily of walking or running.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of active video games (AVGs) versus traditional therapeutic exercise on pain, stiffness, physical function, and other outcomes in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both AVGs and therapeutic exercises similarly improved pain in knee OA patients, but AVGs showed superior improvements in dynamic balance, physical functional performance (e.g., 10-m walking time, stair ascent time), and physical health. No significant differences were found in pain, stiffness, or physical function between the groups over time.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (n=80).
effective_dosage: Treatment was administered 3 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the quality of chest compressions during intrahospital transportation based on the provider's position, including walking next to the bed.
results_summary: Walking next to the bed (group 1) resulted in significantly worse chest compression quality (hand placement and depth) compared to other positions. Participants rated walking as unsafe, unpleasant, and exhausting, favoring kneeling positions instead.
population_specificity: 20 paramedics (8 female, 12 male) with an average professional experience of 4.8 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between types of putaminal hemorrhage and walking independence or the need for orthotic therapy in stroke patients with hemiplegia.
results_summary: The study found that walking independence and the need for orthosis were closely related to the type of hematoma, with 143 patients achieving independent walking (FAC≥4) and 121 not. CT imaging at stroke onset provided useful predictive information for rehabilitation outcomes.
population_specificity: 264 patients with putaminal hemorrhage admitted to Fujita Health University Nanakuri Memorial Hospital, Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a simple inpatient exercise program involving walking and rising from a chair could reduce the incidence of hospitalization-associated disability (HAD) in acutely hospitalized very old patients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significantly lower risk of HAD compared to the control group, with improved ADL function at discharge. No significant differences were found for secondary outcomes like falls, rehospitalization, or death.
population_specificity: Acutely hospitalized very old patients (mean age 88 years, range 75-102).
effective_dosage: Approximately 20 minutes/day of supervised exercises (walking and rising from a chair).
study_duration: Median hospitalization duration was 7 days (interquartile range 4 days), with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the genetic association between PIEZO1 variants and bone mineral density (BMD) in humans, particularly focusing on mechanical forces during walking and physical activities.
results_summary: The study identified 14 top SNPs for PIEZO1, with the best SNP rs62048221 showing a significant association with heel BMD, suggesting that mechanical forces from walking and physical exercises may influence bone formation. Each copy of the effect allele T was associated with a slight decrease in BMD.
population_specificity: Humans (specific demographic details not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multimodal prehabilitation program involving exercise (including walking) could reduce postoperative complications in frail patients undergoing colorectal cancer resection compared to postoperative rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in 30-day postoperative complications, recovery of walking capacity, or other secondary outcomes between the prehabilitation and rehabilitation groups. The prehabilitation program did not demonstrate superior efficacy in improving postoperative outcomes in frail patients.
population_specificity: Frail patients (Fried Frailty Index ≥2) aged 65 years or older undergoing colorectal cancer resection.
effective_dosage: Not specified (multimodal program involving exercise, nutritional, and psychological interventions).
study_duration: 4 weeks before surgery and 4 weeks after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a cross-sectoral cardiac rehabilitation program for patients with intermittent claudication (IC) is more effective than usual care in improving walking capacity and other health outcomes.
results_summary: The study will compare the effects of cardiac rehabilitation versus usual care on maximal walking distance (primary outcome) and pain-free walking distance, healthy diet, and physical activity levels (secondary outcomes). Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC) caused by peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a multicomponent rehabilitation program, including guidance for safe walking, could improve physical activity, sedentary behavior, and mobility in older adults recently discharged from hospital.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in physical activity or physical performance between the intervention and control groups, indicating the rehabilitation program was not superior to standard care. The authors suggested a longer and more frequently monitored intervention might be needed for this population.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 60+ recovering from lower limb or back musculoskeletal injuries, surgeries, or disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if baseline quadriceps and hamstrings muscle activity patterns during walking differed between individuals with knee osteoarthritis who later underwent total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and those who did not.
results_summary: The study found that individuals who advanced to TKA had higher hamstrings activity magnitudes, prolonged mid-stance muscle activity, and greater lateral co-contraction indices during walking, suggesting less joint unloading. These patterns may serve as potential targets for conservative interventions.
population_specificity: 54 individuals with medial-compartment knee osteoarthritis.
study_duration: Follow-up occurred 5 to 8 years after baseline measurements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of canine-related physical activity interventions, particularly dog walking, in promoting regular walking and to identify key characteristics of successful interventions.
results_summary: The review found that canine-assisted interventions generally increased physical activity, with 82% of studies showing favorable changes for the canine-facilitated intervention. Shorter follow-up periods were associated with more pronounced behavior changes compared to longer follow-up studies.
population_specificity: Varied populations, including new dog owners, established dog owners, and individuals using loaner dogs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of exercise prehabilitation (including walking) on the functional status of patients undergoing colorectal resection.
results_summary: The intervention group showed statistically significant improvements in 6-minute walking distance and self-reported physical activity compared to controls, but no significant differences in complication rates or hospital stay length.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing colorectal resection (415 participants across six studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of ultrasound-guided continuous SAPB versus surgically placed continuous thoracic paravertebral block (SPVB) in improving postoperative functional measures, including walking distance, in patients undergoing VATS.
results_summary: The SAPB group showed improved walking distance on Day 1 postoperatively compared to the SPVB group, with statistical significance (p = 0.012). No significant differences were noted in other functional measures like cough strength or overall safety outcomes between the two groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing videoscopic-assisted thoracic surgery (VATS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between walking activity and fall rates before and after an exercise program (V-TIME) in older adults, including those with mild cognitive impairment and Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found that the V-TIME interventions reduced fall risk (measured by the FRA index) without changing walking activity levels, with significant improvements across all groups. The FRA index was higher for fallers with Parkinson's disease at baseline compared to other groups.
population_specificity: Older fallers (n=109), fallers with mild cognitive impairment (n=38), and fallers with Parkinson's disease (n=128).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a resistance exercise and dietary protein intervention for improving muscle strength, lean body mass, and physical performance in older adults in a real-life setting.
results_summary: The intervention group showed improvements in muscle strength, lean body mass, and some physical performance measures (e.g., Timed Up-and-Go) compared to controls, but no significant difference was found for the 6-Minute Walking Test, activities of daily living, or quality of life.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (age 75 ± 6 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified for walking; resistance exercise was supervised, and protein intake was increased under dietitian guidance.
study_duration: 12-week intensive support intervention followed by a voluntary 12-week moderate support intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine which spatio-temporal gait parameters and clinical scales could effectively evaluate motor performance improvements in iNPH patients before and after a cerebrospinal fluid tap-test (CSF-TT).
results_summary: Patients showed significant improvements in cadence and stride length 72 hours post-CSF-TT, with reduced gait apraxia. Clinical scales like Tinetti Gait and Gait Status Scale complemented instrumental data, especially in TUG performance.
population_specificity: 76 patients with idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus (iNPH), including 20 with associated vascular encephalopathy.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention was a CSF tap-test, not a dosage-based treatment).
study_duration: Assessments were conducted before, 24 hours, and 72 hours after CSF-TT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of adaptive servo-ventilation (ASV) on outcomes in patients with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and central sleep apnoea (CSA), including the role of circulating biomarkers in prognosis.
results_summary: The study found no difference in the primary outcome (all-cause death or unplanned HF hospitalization) between ASV and control groups, but higher all-cause and cardiovascular mortality in the ASV group. Three biomarkers (soluble suppression of tumorigenicity 2, Notch-3, and GDF-15) added significant prognostic information beyond the best clinical model.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and central sleep apnoea (CSA), predominantly male (90%), mean age 69 ± 10 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and compliance of a 3-month exercise intervention in older adults and assess whether muscle mass and function changes could be detected using specific measures.
results_summary: Both walking-only and walking combined with strength/balance exercises improved lean mass and reduced fat percentage. The combined exercise group showed greater improvements in jump force efficiency and power compared to walking alone.
population_specificity: Adults aged 70 years or older.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking combined with balance/strength exercises, frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a peer-delivered CBT-based diabetes self-management program in improving physical activity, functional status, pain, and quality of life in individuals with diabetes and chronic pain.
results_summary: The intervention improved functional status, pain, quality of life, and self-reported physical activity despite pain in participants with diabetes and chronic pain compared to controls.
population_specificity: Individuals with diabetes and chronic pain, predominantly African American women with low income and education levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of revascularization versus noninvasive treatment (best medical therapy + structured exercise therapy) for intermittent claudication.
results_summary: After 5 years, revascularization showed no long-term improvement in health-related quality of life or walking capacity compared to noninvasive treatment and was not cost-effective. Early benefits of revascularization were lost over time.
population_specificity: Patients with mild-to-severe intermittent claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of early discharge with interdisciplinary home rehabilitation versus inhospital geriatric care on independence in daily activities, including walking ability, in older adults with hip fractures.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in ADL performance, including walking ability, between the home rehabilitation and inhospital care groups, with both groups recovering their prefracture independence levels comparably by 12 months.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 70+ with acute hip fractures, including those with cognitive impairment and living in residential care facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multicomponent exercise program, including walking, improves health outcomes like walking speed, muscle strength, balance, and fear of falling in older women with osteoporosis and vertebral fractures.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in walking speed (primary outcome) but observed statistically significant improvements in dynamic balance, arm curl strength, 30-second sit-to-stand performance, and reduced fear of falling. No significant differences were found in health-related quality of life.
population_specificity: Older women (65+ years) diagnosed with osteoporosis and vertebral fractures.
effective_dosage: 12-week multicomponent exercise program (specific walking dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe cases of posterior spinal artery syndrome (PSAS) caused by vertebral artery dissection and its impact on walking instability.
results_summary: The study found that two patients with PSAS experienced walking instability, sensory loss, and muscle weakness, but showed good outcomes after antiplatelet therapy and physiotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients with posterior spinal artery syndrome caused by vertebral artery dissection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of FES-aided rehabilitation plans, including assisted walking, on functional recovery after spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found that FES can improve respiration, circulation, hand strength, mobility, and metabolism in SCI patients. It highlighted benefits for upper and lower extremity strength, cardiopulmonary function, and bladder control.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a home-based, remotely monitored intervention using wearable accelerometers, financial incentives, and health engagement questions could increase physical activity (steps) and reduce weight in kidney and liver transplant recipients.
results_summary: The intervention increased the likelihood of achieving ≥7000 steps compared to control, but no significant differences in weight change were observed across the groups. Adherence to step goals was 74%, and 84% of health engagement questions were answered correctly.
population_specificity: Kidney transplant recipients (KTRs) and liver transplant recipients (LTRs) within 24 months of transplant.
effective_dosage: Target step increase of 15% from baseline every 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether motor neuroprosthesis (MN) improves independence in activities of daily living, limb activities, participation, exercise capacity, and balance in post-stroke individuals compared to other assistive devices.
results_summary: The study found that MN was no more beneficial than ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) for improving limb activities, balance, exercise capacity, or participation. MN did not increase falls or serious adverse events but had higher dropout rates during the intervention.
population_specificity: Individuals more than three months post-stroke (total 831 participants).
effective_dosage: MN was used from up to eight hours per day to all-day use for ambulation.
study_duration: Intervention duration varied, with some studies following participants for up to six months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare outcomes, hospitalization length, and total cost between single-stage and two-stage open reduction and PPO surgeries for bilateral DDH in walking-age children.
results_summary: Single-stage surgery showed statistically significant advantages in reduced costs, anesthesia duration, blood loss, and hospitalization period, with no significant difference in preoperative and postoperative acetabular index (AI) outcomes.
population_specificity: Walking-age children with bilateral developmental hip dysplasia (DDH).
study_duration: Not specified (surgical procedure and recovery period).

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of a combined balance-, strength-, and jumping-exercise intervention on a mini-trampoline for improving static balance, functional mobility, gait speed, strength, fear of falling, and bone mineral density in older women with osteopenia.
results_summary: The 12-week intervention significantly improved balance, functional mobility, strength, gait speed, and fear of falling, but did not show significant improvements in bone mineral density at the lumbar spine or femoral neck.
population_specificity: Older women (56-83 years) with osteopenia.
effective_dosage: Twice a week, 45-60 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of preserving or removing posterior epidural adipose tissue (PAT) on postoperative outcomes, including pain and functional status (e.g., walking distance), following lumbar decompression surgery for lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: Postoperative pain intensity and functional status (measured by ODI and walking distance) were worse in the group where PAT was removed compared to the group where it was preserved. No significant differences in surgical outcomes or complications were observed between the groups.
population_specificity: 181 patients undergoing lumbar decompression surgery for LSS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictive factors for infection in adults with chronic leg ulcers over a 12-week period.
results_summary: The study found that using walking aids and having gout were significantly associated with an increased likelihood of developing infection in chronic leg ulcers. These factors may help clinicians identify patients at higher risk of infection.
population_specificity: 65 adults with chronic leg ulcers recruited from an outpatient wound clinic in Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify relevant movement quality domains and appropriate instruments for assessing movement quality in patients with non-specific low back pain during activities like walking.
results_summary: The study found that walking is a relevant activity for evaluating movement quality in patients with non-specific low back pain, but no suitable instruments currently exist to measure key domains like range of motion, inter-segmental coordination, or whole-body movements in daily practice.
population_specificity: Patients with non-specific low back pain (NS-LBP) and healthy controls.
