study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of green space exposure, including walking programs, on sleep quality and quantity.
results_summary: Walking programs, as part of green space interventions, were associated with improvements in sleep quality and quantity, with 11 out of 13 studies supporting this positive association.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a rapid picture-based Clinical Frailty Scale (CFS-9) against the Fried Frailty Index for assessing frailty in older patients with pelvic floor conditions.
results_summary: The CFS-9 scores from surgeons and patients showed substantial to moderate agreement with the Fried Frailty Index, with AUC values ranging from 0.86 to 0.91, indicating it is an excellent predictor of frailty.
population_specificity: Older patients (mean age 73.0 ±5.9 years, 97.2% female) with pelvic floor conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of experimentally induced muscle and mental performance fatigability on gait kinematics, variability, kinetics, and muscle activity in healthy older adults.
results_summary: Muscle performance fatigability increased stride length, width, gait velocity, inter-stride trunk acceleration variability, and ankle muscle coactivation. Sustained mental activity increased step variability during dual-task walking but not single-task walking.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether electromyography biofeedback (EMG BF) therapy improves ankle dorsiflexion and walking ability in hemiplegic patients post-cerebrovascular accident (CVA).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in ankle range of movement, motor function (MMAS), and neurophysiological recovery (Brunnstrom) in the EMG BF group compared to conventional physiotherapy alone. EMG BF also showed significant changes in muscle activity, while spasticity remained unchanged in both groups.
population_specificity: 40 hemiplegic patients post-CVA undergoing inpatient rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: EMG BF therapy applied 5 days a week for 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a tailored prehabilitation program (including exercise and patient education) on physical function, particularly walking speed, in older patients awaiting total hip replacement surgery.
results_summary: The study evaluated gait speed as the primary outcome, along with secondary outcomes like lower body strength, mobility, and quality of life, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults aged 70+ scheduled for primary total hip replacement due to late-stage osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise and education for 6-12 weeks).
study_duration: 6-12 weeks pre-surgery, with follow-ups at 6 weeks and 3 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the effectiveness of rehabilitation programs using interactive video game technology (IVGT) in improving walking capacity for individuals aged 60 years and over.
results_summary: The study found a moderate but significant effect of exergames on walking capacity (SMD -0.56; p = 0.002), with greater effectiveness in improving transfer ability (SMD -1.02; p = 0.003). However, the evidence quality was low due to bias risks like lack of masking and assessor blinding.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 60 years and over.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a hypocaloric diet combined with varying degrees of physical activity (including walking) on body composition in obese adult women.
results_summary: Walking (moderate physical activity at 10,000 steps) resulted in lower body fat compared to a hypocaloric diet alone, but intense physical activity was more effective for reducing body fat and maintaining muscle mass. No significant differences in body weight were found between moderate and intense activity groups.
population_specificity: Obese adult women (117 healthy female volunteers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of physical activity (measured via pedometer) on somatic symptoms in patients undergoing maintenance hemodialysis.
results_summary: Higher somatic symptom scores (S1-score) were associated with lower physical activity levels. Total physical activity showed a strong negative correlation with somatic symptoms (r = -0.813). Patients in the low physical activity group had nearly double the odds of high somatic symptom scores (OR = 1.97).
population_specificity: Patients receiving hemodialysis treatment ≥3 times per week for >3 months, aged ≥18 years, recruited from four hemodialysis centers in Zhejiang, China.
effective_dosage: Physical activity was stratified using a cutoff of 3000 MET-min/week (high vs. low exercise groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supervised multimodal exercise training, including brisk walking, could reduce cardiovascular risk in low-income adults compared to self-directed physical activity or inactivity.
results_summary: Supervised exercise (including walking) significantly reduced cardiovascular risk markers (e.g., cholesterol, blood pressure) by 35%, while self-directed activity maintained risk levels, and inactivity increased risk by 20%.
population_specificity: Low-income adults (ages ~57-61) in Rio de Janeiro favelas, Brazil.
effective_dosage: 50-min exercise circuit twice weekly + 30-min brisk walking once weekly (FA group); self-reported activity twice weekly (DA group).

study_goal: To investigate the highest ambulatory speed achievable by motor-complete sub-acute SCI patients using a Lokomat and assess its safety and effects on vital parameters, pain, and spasticity.
results_summary: The study found that SCI patients achieved an average walking speed of 0.63 m/s in the Lokomat, exceeding typical exoskeleton speeds, with no negative effects on vital parameters or spasticity and a significant reduction in pain.
population_specificity: Six persons with motor-complete sub-acute spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare adherence and health outcomes between sequential and simultaneous introduction of nutrition and exercise (including walking) during pregnancy.
results_summary: Group C (exercise first, then nutrition) showed the highest adherence (80.2%) and better health outcomes compared to Groups A (simultaneous) and B (nutrition first). Walking, as part of the exercise intervention, contributed to improved adherence and positive health effects.
population_specificity: Pregnant women at 12-18 weeks gestation, stratified by BMI.
study_duration: Intervention lasted until 25 weeks gestation for initial behavior, with the second behavior added at 25 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different exercise therapies, including walking (via cycling and exergaming), on clinical and motor symptoms and quality of life in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: Exergaming (EXE), balance (BAL), and cycling (CYC) improved MS-related symptoms similarly, with EXE and CYC also enhancing quality of life and walking capacity more than BAL. Only EXE improved gait and balance scores, while EXE and BAL reduced fall risk and improved standing balance more than CYC.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS), 90% female, average age 47.0 years, with Expanded Disability Status Scale scores of 5-6.
effective_dosage: Five times a week for 5 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maximal strength training (MST) could counteract treatment-induced adverse effects in breast cancer patients undergoing adjuvant therapy, specifically focusing on improvements in muscle strength, functional performance, and walking economy.
results_summary: The MST group showed significant improvements in maximal muscle strength (20%), walking economy (9%), time to exhaustion (9%), 6-minute walking distance (10%), chair rising (30%), and stair climbing performance (12%), while the control group experienced declines in these measures. MST also maintained muscle mass, unlike the control group, which saw a 7% decrease.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed stage I to III breast cancer patients (49 ± 7 years) scheduled for adjuvant therapy.
effective_dosage: 4 × 4 repetitions of dynamic leg press at ~90% of one-repetition maximum, twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in maximal treadmill walking distance versus 6-minute walk distance in response to therapeutic interventions or control in participants with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Participants randomized to control or placebo declined in 6-minute walk distance but improved in maximal treadmill walking distance. Home-based and supervised treadmill exercise improved 6-minute walk distance, with home-based exercise showing greater improvement. Treadmill exercise training significantly enhanced treadmill walking distance, suggesting a training-to-the-outcome effect.
population_specificity: Participants with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and intermittent claudication (mean age 69.8, mean ankle-brachial index 0.66).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare self-perceived functioning, disability, and recovery after electromechanically-assisted gait training (EAGT) versus conventional gait training in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in self-perceived functioning, disability, or recovery between EAGT and conventional gait training groups. Self-perceived mobility was associated with improvements in walking speed/endurance and balance, while self-perceived recovery was linked to ADL ability.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of uphill walking combined with physical therapy versus physical therapy alone on knee pain, excursion ranges, stride length, and walking speed in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that adding uphill walking to physical therapy significantly improved stride length and walking speed post-treatment and maintained these improvements at follow-up, compared to physical therapy alone. It also showed persistent benefits in knee ranges, stride length, and walking speed.
population_specificity: 30 patients with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 8-degree treadmill walking at 1.1 m/s for 30 minutes per session, 10 sessions total.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of extracorporeal shockwave therapy and botulinum toxin-A in treating postburn plantar flexion contracture and improving ankle kinematics during walking in children.
results_summary: Both extracorporeal shockwave therapy and botulinum toxin-A significantly improved dorsiflexion active range of motion and ankle kinematics compared to the control group, with no significant differences between the two treatments.
population_specificity: 38 children with burns and plantar flexion contracture.
effective_dosage: Extracorporeal shockwave therapy (0.2 mJ/mm² once weekly for 4 weeks); botulinum toxin-A (0.5-2 U/kg/muscle group, max 12 U/kg/body weight, single dose).
study_duration: 4 weeks for shockwave therapy; single dose for botulinum toxin-A.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare postoperative outcomes (pain, disability, complications) between full-endoscopic (bi-portal or uni-portal) and microscopic decompressive laminectomy for lumbar stenosis.
results_summary: Full-endoscopic techniques showed statistically significant lower back and leg pain and fewer complications compared to microscopic decompression, with no difference in disability scores or operative time. Subgroup analysis indicated bi-portal endoscopy had better early pain relief, while uni-portal endoscopy had better long-term leg pain outcomes and lower complication risks.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar stenosis undergoing decompressive laminectomy.
study_duration: Follow-up periods varied, including 3 months and last follow-up (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify biomechanical variables correlated with improved walking speed in acute stroke patients following rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found modest improvements in walking speed (0.21 m/s increase at follow-up), with step length and tibia-to-vertical angle changes significantly correlating with speed gains. Despite improvements, the final speed (0.71 m/s) remained insufficient for safe pedestrian road crossing.
population_specificity: Acute stroke patients (within 6 weeks of stroke) exhibiting abnormal gait (mean age 67.7 years, 73.9% male).
study_duration: 6-week rehabilitation phase, with follow-up at 6 months post-stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if blood flow restriction (BFR) combined with walking and other exercises induces muscle hypertrophy and improves strength and physical function in adults over 50.
results_summary: BFR combined with various exercises, including walking, resulted in muscle hypertrophy and improved muscle strength and functional performance, with average effect sizes of 0.75 and 1.15, respectively. However, most studies had moderate to high risk of bias.
population_specificity: Adults older than 50 years, including healthy individuals and those with conditions like cardiovascular disease, osteoarthritis, and spinal cord injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the lung function trajectory and safety profile of azathioprine (AZA) in chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis (CHP) patients, including its impact on walking capacity via the 6-minute walking test (6MWT).
results_summary: AZA treatment was associated with a significant improvement in forced vital capacity (FVC) at 12 and 24 months, with a slight increase in 6MWT performance, though this did not reach statistical significance. No changes in diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) were observed.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis (CHP) diagnosed by a multidisciplinary team.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish standardized measurement methods for assessing physical capacity, including walking, in young and middle-aged active adults with hip-related pain.
results_summary: The study recommended assessing functional tasks like walking and running objectively, quantifying physical activity, and evaluating return-to-sport criteria, but did not provide specific efficacy data on walking itself.
population_specificity: Young and middle-aged active adults with hip-related pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the experiences and perspectives of physically inactive women who completed a mobile phone-based physical activity education (mPED) trial, focusing on sustained engagement in walking post-intervention.
results_summary: The intervention group showed higher rates of pedometer/activity tracker use (49.3% vs. 26.1%) and brisk walking (54.5% vs. 30.4%) compared to controls. Key themes supporting sustained activity included tracking, accountability, motivation, and habit formation, with technology and personal touch playing complementary roles.
population_specificity: Physically inactive women (n=203, from an initial cohort of 210).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify evidence-based examination components to distinguish between idiopathic toe walking (ITW) and cerebral palsy (CP) for accurate movement system diagnosis.
results_summary: The study found differences in clinical findings, walking characteristics, and muscle firing patterns between participants with CP and ITW, enabling better classification and targeted care plans.
population_specificity: Participants with idiopathic toe walking (ITW) and cerebral palsy (CP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a multicomponent exercise intervention versus a walking intervention on physical and cognitive performance, habitual physical activity, affective function, and quality of life in older adults living in long-term nursing homes.
results_summary: The walking group showed improvements in anxiety and quality of life but did not demonstrate significant improvements in physical or cognitive performance compared to the multicomponent exercise group. Both interventions were effective in maintaining or improving affective function.
population_specificity: Older adults living in long-term nursing homes.
effective_dosage: Up to 20 minutes of walking per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify clinical findings most strongly associated with hip osteoarthritis (OA) in patients presenting with hip or groin pain.
results_summary: The study found that simple tests of hip motion and observing pain during motion were useful in distinguishing patients likely to have hip OA on radiography. Specific findings like squat causing posterior pain, groin pain on passive abduction/adduction, and decreased passive hip adduction/internal rotation were strongly associated with OA.
population_specificity: Patients presenting to primary care physicians with hip or groin pain (1110 patients, 1324 hips).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of body-weight supported locomotor training (BWSLT) programs on health-related quality of life (HRQOL) in individuals with long-standing motor incomplete spinal cord injury and poor walking function.
results_summary: BWSLT with manual or robotic assistance did not improve HRQOL, though lower extremity motor scores (LEMS) increased in the BWSLT group compared to the control group. The study was underpowered, and the training programs showed minimal effects on HRQOL, exercise barrier self-efficacy, and motivation.
population_specificity: Individuals with long-standing motor incomplete spinal cord injury and poor walking function.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and radiological outcomes of different types of lag screws (ITST, PFNA, Gamma 3 U-Blade) used in intramedullary nails for trochanteric femoral fractures in elderly patients.
results_summary: The study found that the Gamma 3 U-Blade lag screw had the lowest fixation failure rate (1.5%) compared to ITST (5.0%) and PFNA II (7.0%). The sliding distance of the U-Blade was intermediate between PFNA II (shorter) and ITST (longer).
population_specificity: Patients aged 65 years or older with trochanteric femoral fractures.
study_duration: Surgeries performed between January 2011 and June 2016; follow-up duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to inventory and evaluate outcome measures used to assess orientation and mobility (O&M) performance in adults with vision impairment (low vision and blindness).
results_summary: The study identified a wide variety of O&M outcome measures, with efficiency (time, distance, speed) being the most common, followed by obstacle contacts/avoidance and dis/orientation. Nearly half of the measures met criteria for face validity, responsiveness, reliability, and feasibility, suggesting potential for clinical or functional O&M practice.
population_specificity: Adults with vision impairment (low vision and blindness).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding a timing and coordination component to standard strength, endurance, and flexibility training improves walking ability, mobility, and participation in older adults with slow gait speed.
results_summary: The study compares standard exercise programs with standard-plus timing and coordination programs but does not yet report specific results, as it describes the methods and rationale of an ongoing trial.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults walking slower than 1.2 m/s.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a 12-week combined resistance and aerobic exercise intervention on balance, walking ability, fatigue perception, quality of life, and disease severity in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The combined training improved walking and balance ability, reduced fatigue and depression, enhanced quality of life, and decreased disease severity in MS patients. The intervention was well tolerated and demonstrated functional and psychological benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (combined resistance and aerobic exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical effectiveness of the adapted HiBalance program on balance control and gait in people with mild-moderate Parkinson disease.
results_summary: The training group showed significant improvements in balance performance, gait speed, and dual-task interference compared to controls, but no differences were observed in physical activity levels or patient-reported measures.
population_specificity: People with mild-moderate Parkinson disease (n = 117).
effective_dosage: 10-week HiBalance group training program (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of yoga, pharmacological treatment, dietary interventions, and moderate-intensity walking for IBS.
results_summary: The study found that moderate-intensity walking was equally effective as dietary interventions and yoga in improving IBS symptoms, with benefits seen in both physical and mental health outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with IBS

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the most effective interventions to improve walking speed and timed distance in ambulatory individuals more than 6 months after acute-onset CNS injuries like stroke, motor incomplete spinal cord injury, or traumatic brain injury.
results_summary: Strong evidence supports walking training at moderate to high intensities or virtual reality-based training for improving walking speed and distance, while body weight-supported treadmill training, robotic-assisted training, or sitting/standing balance training without virtual reality were ineffective. Weak evidence suggests benefits from strength training, circuit training, cycling, or virtual reality-based balance training.
population_specificity: Ambulatory individuals >6 months post-acute-onset CNS injury (stroke, motor incomplete spinal cord injury, or traumatic brain injury).
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency, intensity, time, and type of training interventions were detailed but not quantified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety and efficacy of extended-release albuterol as adjunctive therapy for improving motor function, including walking, in patients with late-onset Pompe disease already on enzyme replacement therapy.
results_summary: The study found that extended-release albuterol significantly improved forced vital capacity, forced expiratory volume, six-minute walk test distance, and Gross Motor Function Measure scores, particularly in standing and walking/running/jumping subtests, compared to placebo. No serious adverse events were reported, with only minor transient side effects like muscle spasms and tremors.
population_specificity: Patients with late-onset Pompe disease stably treated with enzyme replacement therapy for 4.9 (1.0-9.4) years and without contraindications to albuterol.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing daily walking steps could reduce the 6-month incidence of neck pain in high-risk office workers.
results_summary: The intervention group (22% incidence) had a significantly lower rate of neck pain compared to the control group (34%), with an adjusted odds ratio of 0.22. However, walking did not significantly reduce pain intensity or disability levels in those who developed neck pain.
population_specificity: Healthy office workers at high risk of neck pain.
effective_dosage: Not specified (participants were instructed to increase daily walking steps to a designated level).

study_goal: To analyze the effect of body weight supported treadmill training with a voluntary driven exoskeleton on walking ability in persons with varying levels of spinal cord injury.
results_summary: Significant improvements were observed in the 10-meter walk test, timed up and go test, and Berg Balance Scale, particularly in participants with high baseline walking ability. No significant improvements were seen in participants with low baseline walking ability.
population_specificity: Twenty individuals with chronic spinal cord injury (ASIA grades A-D) who had reached a plateau in recovery.
effective_dosage: Twenty 60-minute sessions of body weight supported treadmill training with a hybrid assisted limb.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the physiological and health benefits of Earthing (walking barefoot outdoors or using grounding systems indoors) on inflammation, pain, stress, blood flow, energy, sleep, and overall well-being.
results_summary: The study found that Earthing stabilizes physiology, reduces inflammation, pain, and stress, improves blood flow, energy, and sleep, and enhances well-being, with effects often developing rapidly. Some 20 studies reported significant physiological improvements when grounded versus non-grounded.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population implied).
effective_dosage: Routine walking barefoot outdoors or using grounding systems indoors while sleeping or sitting (no specific frequency or duration mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an 8-month multicomponent physical activity intervention on cardiorespiratory capacity, body composition, muscle strength, and bone mineral density in nonagenarians, comparing institutionalized and community-dwelling participants.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved handgrip and knee extension strength in all participants, with greater improvements in community-dwelling individuals. Cardiorespiratory capacity (measured by 6-minute walking test) also improved, particularly in institutionalized participants.
population_specificity: Nonagenarians (aged ~93 years), including institutionalized (100% female) and community-dwelling (75% female) individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a progressive walking program on lower limb muscle size and strength in elderly subjects and whether adding stair-climbing provided additional benefits.
results_summary: The progressive walking program significantly increased thigh muscle thickness and strength in older adults, but stair-climbing did not provide additional training effects. Improvement in knee flexion strength correlated with pre-intervention values.
population_specificity: Elderly subjects (age 69 ± 1 years, height 1.63 ± 0.02 m, body weight 64.5 ± 2.0 kg).
effective_dosage: Continuous walking (weeks 1-8) and interval walking (weeks 9-17); stair-climbing for the combined group (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the functional outcomes and kinematic performance of two knee prostheses (Journey 2 and Attune) in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty during walking.
results_summary: The Journey 2 prosthesis showed improved flexion and rotational freedom during walking, with muscle activation patterns closer to physiological norms compared to the Attune implant. However, the operated side still exhibited incorrect muscle activation.
population_specificity: 26 patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty, divided into two groups (A and B) receiving different prosthetic implants.
study_duration: Data collected between June 2016 and November 2016 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between serum bilirubin levels and clinical outcomes, including 6-minute walking distance, in patients with COPD.
results_summary: Higher serum bilirubin levels were positively associated with longer 6-minute walking distance and better quality of life in the GOLD I-II group, but were linked to a higher risk of acute exacerbation in the GOLD III-IV group.
population_specificity: 535 patients with COPD from the Korean Obstructive Lung Disease (KOLD) cohort, categorized into GOLD I-II (64.5%) and GOLD III-IV (35.5%) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of abdominal vibration stimulation versus walking exercise in bowel preparation before therapeutic colonoscopy.
results_summary: The study found that abdominal vibration stimulation achieved similar bowel cleansing results as walking exercise, with no significant differences in adverse events, procedure time, or patient satisfaction. Both methods outperformed the control group in bowel preparation quality.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing therapeutic colonoscopy.
effective_dosage: Walking ≥3,000 steps during the preparation period.
study_duration: Preparation period before colonoscopy (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate if fine-tuning an existing walking detection algorithm with individualized or group-based thresholds could improve walking bout detection in children with cerebral palsy (CP) and typical development (TD).
results_summary: Individual-based (Indiv) and population-based (Pop) customization improved walking bout detection (higher sensitivity, accuracy, and precision), with Indiv showing the best results. The Indiv method also corrected misclassification of non-walking activities as extremely slow walking.
population_specificity: 20 children (10 with CP, 10 with TD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify studies measuring lower-extremity muscle mechanical function and lower-limb functional capacity in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) and to map associations between muscle strength and functional capacity.
results_summary: The study found that lower-extremity muscle strength, particularly in the weakest limb, explains 20-30% of the variance in lower-limb functional capacity tests, with walking tests being the most frequently performed. Exercise programs focusing on increasing muscle strength and minimizing asymmetry between limbs were recommended.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of two different 28-week chair-exercise protocols on salivary steroid hormones, physical frailty, and functional disabilities in frail older women.
results_summary: Both chair-exercise programs reduced physical frailty and improved steroid hormone responses, particularly DHEA, while the control group showed negative trends in physical frailty and hormone levels.
population_specificity: Frail older women (n=60, age 81.84 years)

study_goal: To determine changes in level of accomplishment, satisfaction in daily activities, social participation, and functional mobility in adults with cerebral palsy more than 25 years after selective dorsal rhizotomy.
results_summary: Adults with CP showed high and stable levels of accomplishment and satisfaction in daily activities and social participation, with functional mobility correlating to these outcomes. No significant changes were noted over time, except for a small change in Housing accomplishment.
population_specificity: 26 adults (median age 35 years) with cerebral palsy and spastic diplegia, compared to 26 matched typically developing adults.
study_duration: More than 25 years post-intervention (selective dorsal rhizotomy)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate clinical, neuroradiological, and genetic features of patients with RARS1-related disease and identify possible genotype-phenotype relationships.
results_summary: The study found that RARS1 variants lead to a spectrum of disease severity, from severe early-onset epileptic encephalopathy to mild disease with preserved independent walking. The most frequent variant, c.5A>G, was associated with mild or intermediate phenotypes, while truncating variants led to severe phenotypes.
population_specificity: 20 patients with biallelic RARS1 variants identified by next-generation sequencing techniques.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the clinical and genetic characteristics of SPG8 disease in Italian patients and compare them with other forms of hereditary spastic paraplegia.
results_summary: The study identified four new mutations in the KIAA0196 gene and found that Italian SPG8 patients exhibited stiffness of the lower limbs, spastic gait, walking impairment, and decreased vibration sense, with adult-onset and no cranial nerve involvement.
population_specificity: Italian patients with SPG8, a rare autosomal-dominant form of hereditary spastic paraplegia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a combined exercise (whole-body electromyostimulation) and nutrition program on gait parameters and functional status in advanced-stage cancer patients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in stride length, gait velocity, six-minute walking distance, bodyweight, skeletal muscle mass, and emotional functioning compared to controls. Sensor-based gait analysis effectively reflected physical status changes.
population_specificity: Advanced-stage cancer patients (56.1% male, mean age 60.0 ± 13.0 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of delirium on short-term outcomes, including walking ability, in hip fracture patients aged ≥70 years.
results_summary: The study found no differences in walking ability between delirium and non-delirium cohorts. However, delirium patients had lower functional gains and worse outcomes in activities of daily living, particularly those with dementia.
population_specificity: Hip fracture patients aged ≥70 years, with a focus on those with delirium and dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether moderate selenium deficiency is associated with worse symptoms and outcomes in heart failure patients, including exercise capacity measured by the 6-minute walking test.
results_summary: Selenium deficiency was linked to poorer exercise capacity (6-minute walking test) and quality of life in heart failure patients, as well as higher mortality and hospitalization rates. In vitro, selenium deprivation impaired mitochondrial function and increased oxidative stress in human cardiomyocytes.
population_specificity: Patients with worsening heart failure (multinational cohort).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing home-based exercise interventions, including walking, for patients with congenital heart disease (CHD) to assess their safety, feasibility, and effectiveness.
results_summary: Home-based walking interventions improved exercise capacity (peak oxygen uptake, walking distance, and walking time) in several studies, with significant improvements reported. However, dropout rates were high (15%), and compliance was poorly reported.
population_specificity: Pediatric (18 months to 16 years) and adult (21-41 years) patients with congenital heart disease.
effective_dosage: At least three times per week, 45 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of shoe features on younger children's gait and compare it to barefoot walking.
results_summary: Shoes increased velocity, step time, and step length but decreased cadence compared to barefoot walking. Peak plantar pressure varied with shoe sole flexibility, with stiff shoes generally showing lower pressure and Ultraflex shoes showing higher pressure.
population_specificity: Typically developing children aged ≤6 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the FORMA repair system in improving tricuspid regurgitation and functional outcomes, including walking performance, in high-risk surgical patients.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in the 6-minute walking test (increase by 21 m) and NYHA functional class, indicating enhanced walking capacity and reduced symptoms in treated patients. However, two-thirds of patients in the compassionate cohort retained significant tricuspid regurgitation at long-term follow-up.
population_specificity: High-risk surgical patients with tricuspid regurgitation (Euroscore II >8).
study_duration: Follow-up at 30 days and ≥2 years for the compassionate cohort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of exercise interventions, including walking, on preventing falls in older people living in the community.
results_summary: The study found uncertainty regarding the effects of walking on reducing falls, with no clear evidence of efficacy compared to other forms of exercise like balance and functional exercises or Tai Chi.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60+ years living in the community.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the causes of non-compliance with adaptive equipment provisions in spinal cord injury patients, focusing on factors affecting walking-related devices.
results_summary: Non-compliance with prescribed adaptive equipment was reported in 49.3% of participants, primarily due to medical-related factors (44.1%) and client-related factors (20.6%). The highest non-compliance was noted for knee-ankle-foot orthosis (50%), often linked to health status improvement and high device costs.
population_specificity: 72 patients with traumatic spinal cord injury, 10 months post-rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the efficacy and safety of the BioVentrix Revivent TC System for treating symptomatic heart failure with left ventricular dysfunction caused by myocardial infarction.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in left ventricular ejection fraction and reductions in left ventricular volumes at 12 months, along with symptomatic and quality-of-life improvements.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic heart failure (NYHA class ≥II), left ventricular dilatation and dysfunction due to myocardial infarction, and akinetic/dyskinetic transmural scarred myocardium in specific regions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of individualized behavior change strategies delivered by neurophysiotherapists on increasing physical activity levels in inactive individuals with MS.
results_summary: The study will assess changes in physical activity levels (primary outcome) and MS-specific symptoms, confidence, and quality of life (secondary outcomes) over a 12-month period, but specific results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS) who are ambulatory but currently inactive.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a mobile-health app in improving physical activity levels, particularly walking, among chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant increases in community ambulation (38.95 min/day) and reductions in sitting time (2.96 hours/day) compared to the control group, suggesting the mHealth app effectively promoted adherence to physical activity post-stroke.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors (41 participants, 24 in intervention, 17 in control).
effective_dosage: Not specified (home ambulation program and 8-week rehabilitation program including aerobic, task-oriented, balance, and stretching exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evolution and current therapy of Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD), focusing on personalized treatment regimens to prolong walking and manage symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that early treatment with steroids and ACE inhibitors, combined with physiotherapy, helps reduce joint contractures and prolong walking in BMD patients. Independent walking is typically maintained until at least the third decade.
population_specificity: Patients with Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD), primarily children and young adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of end-effector technology for gait rehabilitation in stroke patients, focusing on efficacy in older populations.
results_summary: Robotic-assisted gait training was more effective for subacute stroke patients with lower ambulation function, improving independent walking ability. Intensive, repetitive task-oriented training via end-effector devices enhanced gait speed and functional ambulation.
population_specificity: Acute, subacute, and chronic stroke patients, with partial inclusion of older populations.

study_goal: To determine if vestibular rehabilitation combined with standard care reduces dizziness and improves daily functions more effectively than standard care alone in patients with acute vestibular neuritis.
results_summary: Vestibular rehabilitation significantly reduced perceived dizziness at 3 and 12 months and improved self-reported measures (HADS, DHI, VAS-C) at 12 months, but no significant differences were found in standing balance or walking speed.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-70 with acute vestibular neuritis confirmed by videonystagmography.
effective_dosage: Not specified (supervised exercise therapy, individually tailored, supported by home exercises).

study_goal: To determine the effects of a multicomponent physical exercise program, including walking, on cognitive and affective functioning and serum BDNF levels in nursing home residents.
results_summary: The intervention group showed maintained cognitive function and reduced loneliness perception, but no changes in serum BDNF levels. The control group declined in cognitive performance.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents (112 men and women) in Gipuzkoa, Spain.
effective_dosage: Not specified (individualized, progressive multicomponent program including walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of supervised exercise therapy on physiological changes, walking distances, and quality of life in claudicant patients with Peripheral Arterial Disease.
results_summary: Supervised exercise therapy improved walking distances and quality of life, linked to changes in endothelial function, inflammation, muscle composition, and angiogenesis, though physiological mechanisms remain unclear. Despite benefits, supervised exercise is underutilized, with emerging alternatives like community-based or home-based therapies showing promise.
population_specificity: Claudicant patients with Peripheral Arterial Disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy and safety of Shenmai in improving exercise tolerance during cardiac rehabilitation for patients who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting.
results_summary: Shenmai significantly improved 6-minute walking distance at discharge compared to the control group, but no significant differences were observed pre-operation or at 30-day follow-up. One death occurred in the control group and one stroke in the Shenmai group post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary artery disease who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting and could complete the 6-minute walking test without assistance.
effective_dosage: Shenmai injection (100 ml/day) post-surgery until discharge (~9.28 days), followed by capsules (3.6 g/day) for 30 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supervised strength training for the lower extremities combined with protein supplementation, initiated during hospitalization and continued at home, improved mobility in older medical patients compared to standard care.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in mobility between the intervention and control groups at 4 weeks post-discharge. However, highly compliant patients in the intervention group showed a greater increase in daily steps compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Older medical patients (≥65 years) admitted acutely from their home to the Emergency Department.
effective_dosage: Strength training 3 days/week with post-training protein supplementation (specific dosage not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: During hospitalization and for 4 weeks after discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical and functional outcomes of the knee joint after tibial intramedullary nailing via suprapatellar (SP) or traditional infrapatellar (IP) approaches.
results_summary: Both SP and IP approaches resulted in equivalent overall HSS knee scores, with no significant differences in pain, walking ability, or other functional components. However, the IP approach showed superior range of motion (ROM) compared to the SP approach.
population_specificity: Patients with tibial shaft fractures (OTA 42) treated with intramedullary nailing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of post-stroke rehabilitation interventions in improving paretic propulsion, ankle kinetics, and walking velocity.
results_summary: Mixed results were reported for improvements in propulsion and ankle kinetics (14 interventions showed gains), while walking velocity increased in most studies (20 out of 23). Gains in propulsion were linked to interventions that challenged the paretic leg's latent capacity.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with gait abnormalities (group size ≥10 per study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether functional electrical stimulation (FES) improves walking ability in Japanese stroke patients during the convalescent phase.
results_summary: The study compared gait rehabilitation with and without FES (Walkaide) over 8 weeks, measuring changes in maximum walking distance using the 6-minute walk test (6-MWT). Results are pending as the abstract does not report final outcomes.
population_specificity: Japanese patients aged 20-85 with hemiplegic gait disorder (drop foot) due to stroke, within 6 months of onset, and functional ambulation classification 3 or 4.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if unilateral transtibial amputees (ITTAs) provide an effective model for studying long-term muscle disuse and to assess its effects on quadriceps neuromuscular function.
results_summary: The study found that long-term disuse in amputated limbs led to significantly lower quadriceps strength (60-76% reduction), neural activation (32-44% reduction), slower contractile properties, and altered muscle architecture compared to intact/control limbs. These changes were not predictable from short-term disuse studies.
population_specificity: Nine individuals with unilateral transtibial amputations (ITTAs) and nine control subjects.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on habitual disuse, not an intervention).
study_duration: Not applicable (study assessed long-term disuse effects, not a timed intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to present two case studies of intracranial tuberculoma in children and discuss its diagnosis, surgical treatment, and prognosis.
results_summary: The study reported two cases of intracranial tuberculoma in children, highlighting diagnostic challenges, surgical intervention, and the importance of histological confirmation. Walking difficulties were noted in one case as a symptom, but no direct effects of walking were studied.
population_specificity: Two pediatric cases (7-year-old and 6-year-old girls) with intracranial tuberculoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a dynamic ankle orthosis (DAO), a standard double upright ankle-foot orthosis (DUAFO), and no orthosis (CON) on ankle joint kinematics and plantar pressures during walking in healthy adults.
results_summary: The DAO reduced hallux peak plantar pressures compared to CON and DUAFO, and decreased early stance peak plantarflexion angular velocity compared to CON and DUAFO. It also maintained frontal plane ankle motion better than DUAFO, which significantly restricted eversion range of motion.
population_specificity: Ten healthy adults (26 ± 3.8 years; 69.6 ± 12.7 kg; 1.69 ± 0.07 m).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (orthosis use during walking at 1.4 m/s).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether interrupting prolonged sitting with different walking-bout schedules improves glycemic metabolism compared to continuous sitting in sedentary adults.
results_summary: All three walking-bout conditions (3-min, 5-min, and 8-min walks) improved glycemic metabolism compared to uninterrupted sitting, with reductions in mean glucose concentration and glucose area under the curve, both during the 9-h intervention and over 26 h. The effects were statistically significant and consistent across different walking schedules.
population_specificity: 16 inactive, healthy adults (7 men, average age 24 ± 3 years).
effective_dosage: Three schedules: 30-min sitting/3-min walk, 45-min sitting/5-min walk, and 60-min sitting/8-min walk (all at 60% VO2max).
study_duration: Four 26-h laboratory sessions, with a 9-h intervention period per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding TENS to standard rehabilitation care improves pain during walking and mobility in elderly patients after hip fracture surgery.
results_summary: Active TENS significantly reduced pain during walking and increased walking distance compared to sham TENS, but had no additional effect on pain at rest, at night, or sit-to-stand performance.
population_specificity: Elderly patients recovering from Gamma-nail surgical fixation of extracapsular hip fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if changes in motor capacity outcomes (e.g., walking speed) were accompanied by changes in objectively measured motor performance after a 3-month intensive treatment period in ambulatory children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found no significant associations between changes in motor capacity (e.g., Gross Motor Function Measure, walking speed) and changes in motor performance after the intensive treatment period, suggesting that improvements in capacity did not translate to improved performance.
population_specificity: Sixty-five children (37 boys, 28 girls) with spastic cerebral palsy, mean age 7 years and 3 months, Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) levels I-III.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supervised exercise (including walking) during pregnancy improves psychological well-being in late pregnancy and postpartum among women with a high BMI.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of supervised exercise on psychological well-being (measured by PGWBI) or postpartum depression (measured by EPDS) in women with high BMI. The lack of effect may be due to low adherence to the exercise protocol.
population_specificity: Women with a prepregnancy BMI ≥28 kg/m², average age 31.2±4.1 years.
effective_dosage: 3 weekly sessions (35 min of moderate-intensity walking/running and 25 min of resistance training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between gait dysfunction and cognitive decline, including its predictive value for mild cognitive impairment and dementia.
results_summary: The study found that gait changes (e.g., reduced velocity, increased variability, impaired multitasking) are linked to cognitive decline and can predict mild cognitive impairment and dementia. Interventions like physical and cognitive rehabilitation may improve gait in affected individuals.
population_specificity: Individuals with cognitive decline or neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Alzheimer's disease, other forms of dementia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a physiotherapist-led telephone-delivered exercise advice and support intervention for improving knee pain and physical function in people with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The intervention modestly improved physical function at 6 months but not overall knee pain; functional benefits were not sustained at 12 months. Secondary outcomes, including walking pain and pain self-efficacy, showed improvement at 6 months but were similar between groups by 12 months.
population_specificity: People with knee osteoarthritis
effective_dosage: 5-10 consultations with a physiotherapist for a personalised strengthening and physical activity programme
study_duration: 6 months (primary outcomes), with follow-up at 12 months
